Dear Ms. Stenzel:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/18/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024. .

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
Two of 15 new employee records reviewed did not show complaince:
• One record did not show documentation of a child protective service’s
clearance from the state of Missouri where the employee resided the last five
years prior to the employee’s 7/19/2024 date of hire.
• A second record did not show ocumentation of a child protective service’s
clearance from the state of Alabama where the employee resided the last five
years prior to the employee’s 7/16/2024 date of hire.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection November 2023, CAP approved 12/12/2023.
2

CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
Two of 25 employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of the employee's six-month
evaluation due by 11/13/2024 after the employee’s position change on
5/13/2024.
• A second record did not show documentation of the employee's annual
evaluation due by 4/24/2024, per her last evaluation completed 4/24/2023.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection November 2023, CAP approved 12/12/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household must have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from the American
Heart Association or the American Red Cross, or other
institution approved by the department.
One of six opened foster home records reviewed showed the foster parent's CPR/

Repeat Violation Established:

(2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination

(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as

(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an

• R400.12708 Child assessment: A discussion was had with the agency
related to domestic adoptive placements, and ensuring for whatever
available child/birth parent history; that may exist; and if there is none,

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Social work contacts: The agency was advised that ensuring that
workers are consistently documentation quality home visits in their social
work contacts could aid them in clearly showing their efforts with the child
and families.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period:
The first incident related to an allegation that the foster parent pushed the child off
the porch after they had gotten into an argument. The special evaluation showed
the foster mother was pushing the child in a chair toward the door in an attempt to
get the child through the door and outside. The child denied being push off the
porch; said he stumble off of it. The worker was unable to determine if that was the
case or if what occurred was an unintentionally push by the foster parent; but once
the child was outside the foster parent locked the child outside. The special
evaluation assessed that both parties were frustrated with one another, and that the
foster parent’s response was not trauma-responsive; nor sensitive to the child’s
emotional needs at the time. The foster home was found in violation of the
behavior management rules. A corrective action plan for the foster parent included
trauma responsive training, learning to utilize alternative parenting techniques; and
reaching out to workers for help when frustrated.
The second incident related to an allegation that foster parent grabbed and squoze
the child’s arm and yelled in the child’s face. During the special evaluation the foster
parent admitted to grabbing the child’s arm so as to get the child’s attention, not to
cause harm to the child. The foster parent also admitted to yelling at the child. The
8

foster home was found in violation with the foster home’s behavior management
rule. A corrective action plan was developed with the foster family that included the
foster parent learning new parenting techniques to use with the child, learning
techniques on how to lower their frustrations; and the foster family was referred to a
foster care navigator for assistance.
In both of these special evaluations, the agency adhered to departmental
timeframes and rules.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this
licensing period:
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024 Renewal inspection where
it received 15 rule and policy violations.
During this current Interim inspection, the agency received 16 rule violations. This
was an increase of one from the previously stated last inspection. Of these 16
citations, 7 are repeat violations within the last two years (4 are specific repeats
violations from the 2024 Renewal inspection). The agency’s CAP compliance
around these 4 rule violations is as follows: the number of individual cases cited
remained the same with respect to 3 rule violations cited; and the number of
individual cases cited with respect to the last rule violation decreased from 2 of 8
to 1 of 8.
The agency reported despite continued staffing losses it continued to work on its
corrective action plan, and towards compliance in all areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator’s (CA) report dated 10/31/2024. The
CA indicated the agency has experienced numerous staff turnover, ranging from
their program director to direct foster care staff. The agency reported
notwithstanding these staffing issues it has maintained a focus on safety, and it
has become adept at finding ways to sustain and maintain its foster care
department. It has various dually trained staff; and supervisors have been able to
carry cases so as to take burdens off workers. The CA reported new staff are
provided a mentor to aid them; and this has proven beneficial. The agency also
reported they are nearly fully staffed, and the installation of their new program
manager has aided them with staffing, in gaining stability and enhancing key
performance indicators (KPI).
The agency further reported they have implemented their corrective action plan;
and they continue to monitor and gauge its progress by way of quarterly audits
and monthly manager meetings. The agency plans to continue its efforts so as to
promote compliance in all areas.
9

Financial Overview
The agency provided a 2024 annual budget, 2025 projected budget; and its most
recent independent financial audit for the year ended 12/31/2023. A review of
both documents did not reveal any concerns at this time.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, foster care program
manager; manager/domestic adoption supervisor, licensing supervisor; and
adoption supervisor during the Entrance conference and Exit conference; I
interviewed, a licensing worker; domestic adoption/state ward adoption worker,
foster care worker, a state ward adoption worker; and foster care supervisor. The
staff interviewed reported feeling supported, appreciated and kept informed on
matters affecting their roles, and what’s required related to the things the agency
must do to correct noncompliance areas. These staff listed the agency’s strengths
as its dedicated supervisors, the support by management; the chief administrator
being hands on, and a strong advocate for staff; and the size of the agency
(allowing its staff to be close and like a family). Areas of growth needed included,
more contact by licensing department with foster care department in the office;
establishing clearer protocols for emergency placements; more social media
presence to recruit teen foster homes; staff stability/ finding more ways to retain
workers; more discussion about pay raises; and continuing to develop ways to
keep the departments working together and functioning as a total team.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency's site did not reveal any concerns or safety issues.
The agency has sufficient space and equipment for its staff, and records are safely
stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert during this licensing period, which was received on
9/11/2024.
Concern:
The Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) Analyst reported she was unable to
verify the safety of the child and home because the foster parent backed out of two
separate rescheduled home visits, 8/26/2024 and 9/11/2024. The foster parent then
reported she did not want to participate in the audit.
Resolution:
The agency made a home visit to the foster home on 9/12/2024 and verified the
safety of the child and the home. The agency provided a copy of the home visit
sheet it utilized to conduct this home visit. It also provided a copy of a 7/15/2024
letter it had sent to the foster parent advising them of their random selection, and the
need for their participation with the DWCL Analyst/the audit review.
10

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
